title: Ticket #7332: GSI bug with newer OpenSSL
description:
A bug in GSI causes client and server to get out-of-sync with newer versions of OpenSSL (first noticed in Ubuntu 18).

A patch has been applied to our Globus external and submitted to the gridcf GitHub project (https://github.com/gridcf/gct/pull/136).

It's unknown if this can be worked around at the Condor layer.

Original Ticket Description

The GSI auth tests started failing on Ubuntu 18. Investigate why.

To reproduce, create empty directory and place attached Dockerfile in it. From within that directory: 

docker build .
docker run -t -i <imagehash> /bin/bash

#inside docker container:
su - condor
condor_master
sh run_this

If you do this on dumbo.chtc.wisc.edu likely everything is cached. Image id is 0ef6c9db9803

2019-Dec-16 11:20:49 by tim:
Zach tried this test on the build machine and it worked there in env matching the build. Still investigating
2020-Apr-10 07:42:27 by tim:
Bulk change of target version from v080808 to v080809 using ticket-target-mover.

2020-Aug-20 22:38:27 by jfrey:
There's a bug in GSI in function gss_init_sec_context(). When the client side finishes the SSL handshake, if there's a payload to be sent to the server, it indicates that the full authentication protocol is complete. The client then skips the post-handshake data exchange, putting the two sides out of sync. In older versions of openssl, the client SSL code appears to wait for a reply from the server before indicating the SSL handshake is done. On Ubuntu 18, the client SSL code indicates the handshake is done while providing a payload to send to the server. Fixing the bug causes the GSI authentication to succeed on Ubuntu 18. But the GSI test still fails on Ubuntu 20, Debian 10, and CentOS 8.

Additionally, there's a bug in the Condor layer when there's a network error when receiving the post-handshake message from the server about whether it's happy about the handshake. This can cause the client to think the server is happy when it is not.

2020-Oct-19 13:05:59 by zmiller:
CODE REVIEW: The changes to the Condor code look good. I did not review the proposed changes to GSI, and am leaving that for their development team. Resolving.
